Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The influence of plant-plant interactions on pollination and plant reproduction near poleward range margins
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change may alleviate stressful environmental conditions, such as cold temperatures and a shorter growing season, that directly hinder flowering plants in northern regions. In addition, climate change may alter interactions between plants and other organisms. Will competition with neighbors affect whether plants respond to increasing temperatures? Observations and experiments on shrubs and pollinators at different distances from a glacier will answer this question. The scientific workforce will be strengthened through support for the education and training of a doctoral student and participation of undergraduates. Science communication will be enhanced through citizen scientist participation and outreach to middle-school and high-school students.

The stress-gradient hypothesis, which posits that plant-plant interactions transition from being competitive to facilitative with increasing stress, will be extended to include pollinator networks. The low-shrub tundra of Kangerlussuaq, Greenland, which is near the poleward range edge of many plants, including our focal species, Vaccinium uliginosum (Ericaceae) encompasses a gradient of 3 degrees C, which mirrors the expected temperature increase in West Greenland over the next 70 years. Using a vegetation removal experiment, how co-occurring plants affect the reproduction of Vaccinium will be determined. Plant traits associated with pollinator attraction and pollinator visitation will be observed, and pollen supplementation treatments will assess pollen limitation. Fruit set and seed production will be measured to assess pollinator-mediated mechanisms in the stress gradient hypothesis. The outcome will improve understanding of the processes of increasing shrub cover in Arctic tundra.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Global warming may change how species interact with each other. For example, a warmer climate can alter pollinator visitation to flowers, herbivore consumption of plants, or competition between plant species. Understanding these ecological implications of climate change are important because they may have repercussions on the survival, reproduction, and distributions of plants and animals. Pollination is an especially important interaction, with about 80% of plants requiring or benefitting from pollinators for fruit and seed production.

Our research goal was to test the hypothesis that warming increases competition between neighboring plants, leading to changes in plant reproduction. Plants may compete for abiotic resources, such as water or nitrogen, as well as for biotic resources, such as pollinators. Despite the importance of pollinators for plant reproduction, previous studies have largely ignored how warming may influence the interactions between neighboring plants and pollinators. We focused on species interactions in the rapidly warming Arctic. As a result of this warming, Arctic tundra landscapes that were once dominated by small herbaceous plants and dwarf shrubs are now becoming increasingly dominated by tall, expansive shrubs that can take advantage of the warmer conditions. Our previous research based on field observations suggested that in warmer conditions, tall willow shrubs and other neighboring plants may outcompete dwarf blueberry (Vaccinium uliginosum) for pollinators, leading to reduced blueberry fruit production. In the funded project, we experimentally tested whether dwarf blueberry faces increased competition from neighboring plants in warmer environments.

Our experiment was conducted along a natural temperature gradient from the Greenland Ice Sheet to a fjord in Western Greenland. Compared to near the ice-sheet, the fjord-end of the gradient had higher shrub cover and was 3° C warmer, which corresponds to the predicted temperature increase in western Greenland over the next 70 years. We found that experimentally removing vegetation or flowers around dwarf blueberry did not alter pollinator visitation, pollen limitation (an increase in pollen limitation would be expected if there were fewer pollinators visiting blueberry flowers), or fruit or seed production at either end of the temperature gradient. Therefore, our experimental results showed no evidence that dwarf blueberry reproduction was influenced by changing interactions with neighboring plants. The experimental results suggest that over the course of one year, neighboring plants may have only small effects on blueberry’s pollination and fruit and seed production.

This project contributed to the final dissertation chapter of a PhD student, who successfully defended her dissertation a year after the award was received. Throughout this project, we promoted science and science communication through assistantships and public outreach. We hired three undergraduate field and lab assistants, who gained skills and experience in research design, data collection, sample processing, and data analysis. We used several avenues to accomplish our outreach goal of increasing the public’s understanding of polar regions. We partnered with the Joint Science Education Project to share our research through hands-on science lessons with a group of American, Greenlandic, and Danish high school students at a field school in Kangerlussuaq, Greenland. Using our pollinator visitation time-lapse photos, we ran a pilot program on an online citizen-science platform where the public sorted through our images of bees and flies visiting flowers to help us quantify pollinator visitation in the Arctic. This work was presented at an Arctic entomology conference to encourage the use of time-lapse cameras and citizen-science platforms. We also brought a middle school teacher to Greenland to learn and work alongside us and conduct outreach during and after fieldwork. This collaboration resulted in several middle school lesson plans on polar science, available through polartrec.org. Finally, the researchers shared their research with four K-12 classrooms, reaching more than 150 students.
